reviewText: Veronica Mars is definitly on its way to be one of the best shows ever. Veronica Mars is witty, spunky, and everything a teenage detective should be. As soon as this show starts I am glued to the T.V. This show has sex, mystery, and murder. Making it an excellent show. People need to spread the word about Vernonica Mars. Now that the second season will come I'm eager for the first season to come in DVD. So I can see it all over it again a million times. Veronica Mars is the best show and I enocurage you to watch it ! It is on UPN tuesdays at 9:00 pm time.

This show is so clever and witty!  I love the fast-paced/ quippy dialogue and you really get in to the characters!  Every week, I'm counting down the days until the next episode!  I heard they've recently said there will be a second season- but I'm hoping they will put out the 1st season on DVD as well!  This is the best show I've come across in a long time- It's only a matter of time before it catches on!!!
I hope when the first season is over, they make a DVD box set of the show. It's a good show, and I hope they make a second season.

I enjoyed this show!  It's well written. The directing, production design, and actors bring depth to what is, really, a teenage soap opera. Unfortunately, I've noticed a pattern with Amazon Prime Video.  I will begin watching a series that is included with Prime, and when I am about half-way through the show Amazon will remove it from Prime.  I'm curious to find out what happens through the rest of the series.  But I'm not going to pay to watch it.

So glad I decided to watch this classic show. I enjoyed Kristen Bell on House of Lies, so when I saw the Veronica Mars movie I decided to watch it. Well, I loved it. I don't want this to sound sexist or backward sounding but at first glance- me, a straight 30-year-old male- loving this show, seems out of place. Well, prepare to be surprised at how appealing this show can be to ANYONE.  For those of you who like mystery-comedy genre types, this is right up your alley. (Think teenage-but serious still- Kiss Kiss Bang Bang). With the show being in a high school setting it's surprising how serious the issues they tackle are. The best issues/performances though are easily those of Bell. They tackle topics such as: serious things like teenage pregnancy, teacher-student relationships, drugs, date-rape all the way to mild things, like your typical high-school love triangle; all in a believable and fresh manner. Seeing how Bell handles (or tries) everything that's thrown at her is a testament to her acting and the equally impressive writing of her character. She is so on point with Veronica. I don't remember the last time I saw an actress play such a believable, strong female lead. The only writing in the show that I found to be poor was that of the sheriff. He was so unbelievably dense, and a bit out of place compared to the rest of the characters. They did try to give him some depth in a season 2 episode but there was no follow-up. From that episode, I was certain it wasn't the actor that was poor, just the writing of him. For that to be the only truly bad writing example I can think of though, it's nothing in the grand scheme of things. However, I didn't watch the show until a year or two later! I burned through the whole series in a (sick) week. The first two seasons are fantastic. Season three is good but not even close to the first two. Also, the final episode was such a letdown. I had no idea it was the final because all the other seasons had 22 episodes. When the 3rd season ended on 20 I thought Amazon maybe was pulling something and wanted people to pay for the final 2 haha. I wish that were the case. I was so let down that THAT was it. The movie puts a nice little bow on things, though. Having said all that, the characters are so loveable and memorable and with the movie kind of tying everything up, I was extremely greatful to have found the show. Watch the first 5-6 episodes. YOU WILL BE HOOKED.

Kristen Bell's acting steadily improves at about the same rate as the story lines decline.  By Season Three, through a blend of facial expressions, body language, and vocal delivery, she has brought to life in 'Veronica Mars' a unique and formidable character.  'Mac' is also an engaging, and more importantly stable, character.  In my opinion, all the other principal characters are vividly colored in most cases but somewhat two dimensional.  Season Three begins to turn justice-seeking Veronica into revenge-seeking Veronica.  When Veronica's notion of punishment starts to wildly exceed the nature of the crime, she becomes less likable and less attractive to have around.

This series has been on my maybe list for a long time. The show seemed like something I would enjoy, but I was wary of all the hype I had heard over the years. As it turns out, Veronica Mars definitely exceeds my expectations. It is fun and suspenseful and clever in a way that is not too cute. It approaches the subject of high school with respect and sensitivity in a manner that does not come off as an afterschool special and also manages not to insult the intelligence of the audience. It is also fun to see early appearances by young actors who have grown into successful careers.

I expected it would be a standard teen drama, and it seems pretty formulaic the first few episodes. The writing is great, however, and multiple storylines get woven together seamlessly and cleverly. I am especially impressed with Enrico Colantoni and with the development of his character. Most teen-centric series end up with parental figures that are barely placeholders in the plot line, but here's a well-developed and well acted father figure. Jason Dohring is also a pleasant surprise as the series wears on, with his portrayal of Logan Echolls being one of the deeper, multi-faceted characterizations. The writing is witty and often so clever that great jokes fly under the radar in the pace of the conversation.
My favorite aspect of the writing, however, is that the wrap up of cases is rarely what the viewer expects, so it keeps you watching as much for mystery as for the relationships onscreen. A great first season.

I love watching this show. I can't wait to watch season two. A High School girl can get away with so much more than an adult. It helps the character to be young with a good imagination. Very cleverly written. She is a loyal friend and sincere person dabbling close to lifting the lid on Pandora's Box. There is an essence of naive youth to Veronica's character, but she also has the drive and courage of a lion. I like that there is no swearing or severe violence in this series. It's fun to watch.

I like this sassy, clever youngster! Although I am much, much older than the characters in this now decade-old series, I still enjoy watching the young navigate their worlds. I've only watched six episodes, but I have for the most part enjoyed them. Of course, I don't always agree with Veronica's decisions, and some of the events ("spoiler alert!") seem to be a bit too good to be true, like the sudden appearance of handsome, glib Troy or Veronica's dismantling of the two college boys' "Nigerian scam." However, in the interest of just relaxing a bit, I can suspend belief and just go with it. The investigation by Veronica and her dad, separately, and soon, I suspect, together, of the death of Veronica's best friend Lilly is a nice, ongoing teaser, and I've already developed my choice of who the real killer is, so I'm curious to see if I'm correct. Overall, despite a few weaknesses (a couple of the characters seem mis-cast and a few situations sketchy), I am enjoying this sort of coming-of-age story and the ever-present class war between the haves and have-nots and how quickly one can go from having it all and being part of the clique to being an outcast, as Veronica finds out. This is a "sorta Valley Girl-ish," (teen noir?) spin on the precariousness of one's position within "power" structures in high school; for example, there are high school "Pirate Points" for the privileged cliques, which are threatened in one episode by a high school election that might put one of the have-nots in the student council president position (I won't reveal anymore!). Kristen Bell's performance is strong and authentic, and she plays well the typical angst-ridden teen, tempering it with her savvy, courage, and compassion for others. The other characters mostly play their parts well, especially the snobbish Logan Echolls (played by Jason Dohring). If you like watching portrayals of teens, their struggles, and the machinations they undertake and experience, you can't go wrong with Veronica Mars. It lasted for only three seasons, so it might make for a good weekend or two of binge-watching.

A severely underrated show.  A friend described it as Buffy the Vampire Slayer, with mysteries instead of demons. Both shows have a strong female lead character, intelligent plots and sharp dialog. They both include season-long story arcs, but VM's season one arc is more intricate, more compelling, and has far more twists than any of the BtVS arcs. It takes 3-4 episodes to get going, but after that, it's totally binge-worthy.  Acting ranges from good to excellent, with Kristen Bell, Jason Dohring, and Enrico Colantoni doing most of the heavy lifting.  12 years after its premiere, it's also great to watch for guest stars, young(er) and old(er).  This is the best of the three seasons, although season 2 is no slouch either.  Well worth your time.

A friend told me that it was a fun show...so I gave it a shot.  It just happened that my 13-yo daughter joined me for the first episode.  It has now turned into a regular show for us, and I'm regularly asked when I get home from work, "Can we watch an episode tonight?"  It's been a great show for us as Dad/Daughter for many reasons.  Veronica's Dad is a normal guy, hard-working and absolutely loves his daughter, and tries to do the right thing.  It's rare to see such a good role model on TV for a dad.  Veronica herself is flawed but sharp as a tack and does the right thing, yet another good role model for my daughter to watch.  Despite there being some awkward topics (purity test, sex, abuse, rape), the show as become a great platform for my daughter and I to talk about these issues in a safe way.  The story is complex and well thought out.  It reminds me a little of the "whodunit" complexity in Twin Peaks, but without the bizarreness and with more common modern social problems.  I look forward to future episodes.

Snarky, seemingly genuine, cute, and doesn't let anyone get in her way... What's not to like about Veronica Mars?  Ok, not every episode in Season 1 holds my interest but I love the whole series and recent movie too much to nitpick.

At first, I watched Veronica Mars in reruns on the Soapnet channel and I found it entertaining to some degree. By watching the first season and pilot episode, you get to understand what makes the series appealing to the audience. The series stars Kristin Bell in the title role. She does a superb job in carrying the series but she has an excellent supporting cast especially Enrico Colantoni (Just Shoot Me and Person of Interest) who played Keith Mars, her father and private investigator. Corinne Bohrer is excellent as Veronica's estranged mother.

Veronica Mars was once in the in-crowd but is now on the outs with most of the school. Her best friend Lily Kane was murdered mysteriously. Lily is played by Amanda Seyfried in flashback scenes. Kyle Secor plays Jake Kane (Homicide: Life on the Streets), the bereaved, guilt-ridden father. Ironically one of his "Homicide: Life on the Streets" co-star Melissa Leo (Academy Award winner for "The Fighter) has a memorable guest appearance in "Meet John Smith" episode. For a small part, she truly delivers. Too bad, Leo and Secor never had a scene together.

Other guest performers include Jane Lynch before "Glee;" real life couple, Harry Hamlin and Lisa Rinna as a movie star and socialite wife; and more. Harry Hamlin gives a surprising tough performance as a movie star with secrets. Everybody has secrets, Veronica Mars wants to solve her best friend's murder even if uncovering unpleasant truth about herself.

The six DVDs feature the entire first season and twenty extra minutes of deleted scenes for each episode. If anything, I would have liked to know about the behind the scenes and the conception of the series especially an interview with Rob Thomas.

Veronica Mars is a fantastic show - the greatest since Twin Peaks. I feel very sorry for those who can't appreciate its incredible acting, suave and wry humor, amazingly detailed storytelling and hyper-complex characters. The massive amounts of angst and intensity among these high schoolers is the only unrealistic (or rather, surrealistic) aspect of the show, and it is forgiven because this is an superbly crafted exercise in stylized fiction and symbolism.

The names, for one thing - Neptune, Tritons, Mars -, are not only planetary, but mythological. Neptune is a cold, distant place, but reluctant gods of war inhabit it. Keith and Veronica Mars do not instigate war, but when others declare it on them, they prove supremely good at it.

The show represents one of those very rare couplings of a great concept, great writing and great directing with a remarkable actress who totally "gets" the whole complex atmosphere of it, and can act the part perfectly. Kristen Bell is an incredible actress (I, for instance, became aware of this show solely because I took an interest in Bell after seeing her tiny but impressively acted part in the movie Spartan); she has every conceivable facial expression completely nailed, and on top of that she is also fabulously gorgeous - all the more so because of her obvious intelligence.

Veronica Mars is, as far as I'm concerned, one of the two best American TV-shows I've ever seen, and my rating of it would be 9 or 10.

This show WILL go down in history as a timeless TV classic.

"We used to be friends" when this show was first on. Veronica Mars as played by Kristen Bell is so tough on the outside and vulnerable on the inside that you wanted to give her a hug but weren't sure she'd like it. (Except from her Daddy, of course.) Enrico Colantoni is great as her Dad, BTW. This is an unusual coming-of-age story, a non-supernatural "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (or so "Buffy" creator Joss Whedon must have thought because he became a "Veronica" fan). The humor is sometimes too thin, but welcome whenever it appears. The soap opera that is Neptune, California, the mythical town where the story is set, is not to be taken too seriously. Veronica gets to solve mysteries very cleverly, not always as many steps ahead of her crime-solving Dad as she thinks. The Big Bad/Red John is the murder of her best friend, which hangs over the whole series until Veronica and her Dad finally solve it. By then the viewer will be hooked on the characters. Maybe hooked enough to want to see their story continue in a movie or novelizations. (Both of which have been done with mixed results.)

This show is EXCELLENT!! I got addicted to it right away. The scripts are well written. The relationship between Veronica and her dad is real and not what tv tends to churn out that the parent is stupid and kid is smart. I wished I had watched this show when it was originally on. Instead, I started with the movie, got very interested in it and wanted to see the series. The relationships are true and tangled. They did a great job developing the whole cast and not just writing Veronica as the only star of the show. The supporting cast is great. There are lessons to be learned too. Great job Rob Thomas. I wish you'd bring back the series since the movie did the perfect setup for it. I am going to be upset when I make to the end of season 3. I am hooked!! I'd love to either see a sequel to the movie or a series. I prefer a series. PLEASE BRING VERONICA AND HER CAST BACK!!! I miss them!! This review written by Reg Dunlop's wife. As the episodes go on it starts to pull at threads of the primary mystery which leaves a dark cloud over the town, well more like that cloud that follows Veronica around all the while several other incidents happen developing the supporting characters making them all very interesting people to invest your time watching.

Well... I was really surprised when my wife wanted to start watching this series. I said, we ran out of things to watch...why not? To my surprise, I'm actually really into this series and can understand why it was a big thing "back then". Some of the episodes you can get an idea of what is going to happen but they have twists that make you go...darn you got me and I want to see what happens next. The theme song is super catchy too! I find myself humming it sometimes at work. If you are like me and ran out of things to watch and want to watch something like a younger CW Mysteries series, this is for you. I hope this helps! Veronica Mars is one of my favorite fictional characters ever. She's cute, tiny, spunky and God help you if you ever wrong her. She had the perfect life going and then one day it all fell apart. Her best friend was killed, her boyfriend dumped her, her dad lost his job and her mom ran away. Then to make matters worse something terrible happens to her at a party & no one believes her or wants to help her. Any other 16 year old would had called it a day, not Veronica. She becomes this very strong girl that will get revenge for what happen to her. She will figure out who killed her best friend and get her dad's reputation back. Veronica Mars would rule the world if she was a real person!!!

The most underrated show of the century. There's a reason it was beloved enough to get a massive kickstarter campaign. I started watching it because of the kickstarter hubbub and wished I'd watched it when it was on the air, so it could have kept going.

Kristen Bell is quirky, charming, and smart. The characters are lovable, the mysteries fascinating, the plot is surprising, and the show tackles relevant, modern themes that we actually deal with. It's not just a show about the popular kids being popular--it's about class warfare, racism, or as the show calls it "the Haves vs. the Have Nots." A seriously underrated show and one of the best television has to offer. WATCH IT, if for no other reason that Logan Ecchols, my most beloved badboy of all time.

This program is better than I thought it would be.  Kristen Bell is excellent in the lead and is complimented by the supporting cast.  The writing is good for what is basically a crime drama.

Set in a So Cal high school, there is a good bit of social angst between the uber wealthy students and their classmates of ordinary means with the well to do frequently asserting their privilege.  The divide is probably too exaggerated to be reflective of reality but certainly provides a playing field for continuing dramatic tension.  It is easy to root for the heroine as she repeatedly gets the best of everybody.

So far it is an enjoyable binge watch before the fall season gets under way.

VERONICA MARS' Scooby Doo-type mystery of the week was never a big draw for me. Don't get me wrong, I'm all for watching a pretty blonde gal solve crimes, kick ass, and catch criminals. If you like your TV shows on the "charming and witty" side, chock full of memorable characters and teen angst galore (and who doesn't?), you should give VERONICA MARS a try.

Since Amazon's digital capacity is so obviously vast, some of us are curious as to why that doesn't carry over to the quality of our video experience.
Amazon is a remarkable service provider in many ways and at such a level that it seems odd that it should fall short in video.
Some of us are trying to figure that out.

Rob Thomas you are a genius!  I came late to this series and was prepared to hate it due to teen subject matter.  However, the writing is kitchy, smart and self-reflexive....listen closely to dialogue for references from everything from old movies (film noire to screwball comedy), to wacky pop culture.  Yes, some teen characters are annoying and several seasons into the series there are some repeated themes that get played out, but over all I am a convert to all things headed by Mr. Thomas....you make TV dialogue worth the listen.  And you may just get sucked in to a fun female teen lead character, by the end of the season I was a hooked "marshmallow."

Everyone already knows this is one of the best tv series ever made.  Interesting concept, good writing, acting, directing, pokes fun at school, film noir, acting, and much else, all the while telling interesting stories with surprising plot twists and multiple subplots.  Features sex and violence without being graphic about them.  'High school' students are all in their mid twenties, which the writers explain by ignoring.  The cost is suspension of disbelief; the valuable payoff is increased focus in behavior and more interesting story lines.  The poor subhuman television executives who cancelled this masterpiece probably thought it cost too much.  Fortunately, there are a lot of episodes, and it never got to jump the shark.

Simply one of the best shows ever, particularly Seasons 1-2. Thank God for streaming as I wasn't smart enough to watch it when it aired on the CW. And note that it is not just for teen viewers. I'm an adult who got hooked. Also fun for me was the locale as I live in San Diego and enjoyed seeing local sites as background for the fictional Neptune.

Veronica Mars is an excellent TV show with great mystery, action, and comedy. The biggest flaw is the dvd case. All 6 discs are stacked on top of each other rather than in different sections of the case (a good example is Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Season 3 from shout factory) or in tiny dvd cases per dvd or 2 in a set (a good example is Firefly: The Complete Series), so if you want to watch an episode from later in the season, you have to take discs on top of them off first. I don't own any shows or movies that I download. This show, I'd consider (especially if the discs start to become unreadable and I've already started to have a few skipping on my discs), that or buy a different dvd case to put my discs on. A good thing I can say is that it was decently priced on Amazon (around $13).

I never paid attention to Veronica Mars until a Kickstarter campaign raised $5.7 million in 2013.  And still I slept on this show. So now in January of 2015, I'm hooked.  I'm a Marshmallow.  The show is superbly written with a great balance of good characterization, comedy, and drama.  There are a few over and underplayed roles, but it's season one.  Most of the acting is good and most of the main characters seem to have good chemistry, especially as the show progresses.  It's a little predictable at times, but I feel it has a more than decent multi-plot story.  If you like murder mysteries, light humor, and can sit through the California High-school backdrop, you'll like the show.

Highly recommended if you like any kind of mystery or just plain well written and well acted television. This is right up there with some of my favorite TV ever.

Veronica Mars doesn't get caught up into the regular school girl routine. There are times that she might like to but she is not that type of person. What she does get caught up into is other peoples lives and helps them out. This season shows you how people get tangled up into unwanted situations and how they respond to them. Sometimes they do the right thing or the wrong thing or just don't know what to do. Then there is Veronica Mars who is smart and street savvy. She helps others in need even when she at first glance you would question that choice. She brings out the goodness in ourselves and our humanity. Plus, it is interesting and enjoyable to see how she gets into and out of trouble. The writers and actors of this series really hit home on people interactions and their dealings with each another.

I recently started watching this series and I have to say it was better than I expected.  The main character is the daughter of a PI who was the former Sheriff.  Veronica Mars helps her dad with some of his PI duties and does a little sleuthing on the side for her high school classmates.  Her character is witty, tenacious and smart.  Her high school classmates are made up of the very wealthy and the not-so-wealthy, so there is some rivalry between the classes.  Season one follows the murder investigation of Veronica Mars' best friend, Lilly, while still introducing other main characters of the story and solving various problems in each episode.  Some of the problems relate to the central murder investigation and sometimes not.  I enjoyed the show very much and was pleased to see that several of the main characters were allowed to evolve and develop throughout the season.  The episodes are varied enough to not get boring while still pushing along the central plot.  I look forward to seeing where her character goes in the future.

Just discovered it and enjoy every show-sort of strange as I am a 67 year old guy watching high school kids, but I still remember my school days. I wish some network would pick it up for more seasons. One of the many reasons I like Amazon Prime!!

It's Nancy Drew meets Columbo.  Definitely recommend to any 90s child, you will feel lots of nostalgia for high school!

Quirky, fun, and relatively innocent show.  While there is some inappropriate sexual material, generally this show has fun characters, with a uniquely strong high school female lead character leading the way.  From one episode to the next Veronica and her friends and enemies are taken through mini-mysteries as Veronica tries to maintain focus on the big whodoneit that is the overall story arch for the entire season.  The characters are generally well written, although some are a bit obviously cliched, I'm looking at you Logan Echolls and Duncan Kane.  Otherwise, a fun show that includes mysteries that don't have you feeling depressed or scared for your life like Law and Order or Criminal Minds may.

I never watched Veronica Mars when it was on prime time TV.  Had I known what I was missing back then I would have paid more attention.  One of the great things about having a kindle coupled with Amazon Prime is that I can go back and watch series that I missed because I was busy with other people and things in my life.  I wasn't sure I would like this series but I got sucked in during the first episode.  I just had to find out who killed Lily among other things.  One of the best parts of the series is the relationship between Veronica and her father.  I do get a little tired of the "haves and have nots" card being played all the time but this is TV and conflict makes things interesting.  I think Veronica is smart, resourceful, and like that she is not perfect.  She makes mistakes but always solves the case.  The series is about teenagers and has some drinking, sex, violence, murder, partying and just plain snottiness. I wouldn't let younger children watch it.

I just started watching this series and really enjoyed it. In fact I watched all three seasons and the movie too. I find that Veronica found a way to endure the social pressure of high school by becoming an amazing detective. The stigma of her father's dismissal as Sheriff and their financial deficit compared to the other wealthy students with their famous or infamous parents influenced her coping with the slights, and smirks of her fellow classmates by ignoring them and doing her own thing. Soon she becomes the " go to " girl when someone has a problem that they can't solve and don't want to go to the authorities.  I'm just so sorry that the show had been cancelled, when it could have gone on through college.

In a somewhat backward discovery, we began watching the Veronica Mars television series after we had viewed the 2013 Veronica Mars movie.  We thought the character of Veronica Mars and the plot of the movie showed some interesting themes, language and situations in contemporary society.  We had never watched the Veronica Mars television series prior to seeing the film on HBO.  The Veronica Mars series (Season One) is o.k.  The series has the same cast members attending Neptune high school, and the pranks, situations and private detective discoveries each episode are, at times, corny and high-schoolish.  That said, a viewer continues to discover the unfoldings of the Veronica Mars' (Kristen Bell) character as the season one advances--relationships with peers, developing values, and confronting life's situations.  As older viewers, we are more "fascinated" than "intrigued."

This isn't a silly kids' story, but one that is fun to watch. Veronica's father was the sheriff of their small town where a wealthy man's daughter was murdered.  The sheriff suspected the girl's father did it but he never had conclusive evidence.  The wealthy man, embarrassed by the suspicions about him, had the sheriff fired.  Veronica's father is now working as a private detective and she is his "girl Friday".  Veronica's mother left them soon after the sheriff was fired and, so far, this is a continuing theme as Veronica attends high school by day and does her own detective work at night for her friends and looking for her mother.

 I am a Kristen Bell fan and she does a great job as a teenage sluth.  The first couple of episodes were interesting and well done.  The second related somewhat to the first.  Now, I have watched 3 and 4 and they are not as good and are "stand alone" episodes, so I'm only giving this one 3 stars. The hunt for Veronica's mother and the truth about why she left is the only relating factor.

 I'll continue watching hoping the writers do a better job.

One of my favorite shows ever.  I first watched after writer Dennis Lehane (also a huge favorite of mine) complimented it in an interview.  Veronica Mars (the series and the character) are both fluffy and tough.  The plotting, writing and character development were excellent.  And I will watch anything Rob Thomas is involved in.  (He, Joss Whedon and David Milch create universes I want to spend my alternate lives in.)  There's a reason fans funded a movie sequel.  They (and I) miss these characters immensely.  I am a grown adult with a rich, full and (sometimes) exciting life and I STILL want to be Veronica Mars when I grow up.  :)  BTW, Season 1 was the my fave (before the network got too involved in dinking around with it - don't get me started on networks.  They ruin a lot of good stuff.)

Just be glad you are not on her list to be looked at closer.  The writing, the arcs, the characters, the PACING and the deliverance of justice are the best aspects of this series that was too good to be true and a must-watch.  You have to follow closely all the clues and trails they leave you for if you fail you will wonder how they arrived at each station of review and delivery.  Pause each time someone who is watching leaves the room.  Just because you like someone does not mean they are free of either scrutiny or actual and deliberate wrong-doing for which they will get what they deserve.  This is just the first season of tight plot-lines and snappy repartee delivered by titled heroine who is not without her own foibles and poor judgment along the way.  Aside from Veronica, my favorite characters were Logan and Weevil.  Let's no try to understand why they and their friends tread their paths but enjoy the problems in which they embroiled themselves requiring Veronica's help near weekly to either get out of or find the better-lit path on which to tread.  Marathon watching is best!!!  Onto to Season Two!!!

Veronica Mars is one of my favorites. I loved the series when it first aired, and it has been fun seeing the series in quick succession. Although Veronica, played by Kristen Bell, is not always believable as a high school student because she has so much freedom, is so gifted at PI work, and looks and acts a bit more mature than most high schoolers, she is fun and sweet. I like the mysteries that run through the series about who killed Lilly Kane and what happened to Veronica's mother. Most of all, I like the fact that the series is engaging without undue violence and gore.

Veronica Mars a cast of thirty plus old adults posing as high school kids you got to love Hollywood and their recycling of child stars past their prime. Veronica Mars is a wonderful combination a valley girl gone Nancy Drew with a healthy taste for sex and mystery. Her dad Mathesar alien leader of the Thermians is transformed into a bumbling Private Investigator resembling Red Skelton The Fox. The cast spends so much time slipping each other the tongue we lose focus on the very laughable plots. We real in horror that anti-social PCH biker gang lead by Eric Von Zipper on vespers.  This biker gang presents us violence in the form of taping wannabes to the high school flag pole hardly the Sons off Anarchy stuff. We are to believe that Veronica who spends more time in the back seat of a car is outraged when she wakes up and realizes she has been drugged and sexual assaulted at a party. Still nothing slows Miss Mars down whether it is finding a killer, solving a crime or switching lovers faster than Heidi Fleiss the million dollar madam of Hollywood.

i'm probably too old (age not included) to be saying I like this  ... while its geared to teenagers (and I'm pretty much a dinosaur) ... it is  a smartly done "aimed at youth" detective show ... again, I like the approach of having an ongoing mystery from episode to episode, yet within each episode there is a side-plot story that is introduced and resolved ... the music is good too. and there are enough twists and turns to allow for the development of somewhat complex characters as the season progresses. so there are some surprises along the way etc. ... basically, just a fun show to watch as I'm clocking in another mile on the treadmill

Kristen Bell shines as Veronica Mars. She is smart as a whip and uses her intelligence to solve crimes as well as help her friends.  I never even knew about this show until I saw it on Amazon streaming video. At first I thought it was a young kids show (as most of the characters are in high school), but as I watched it I became hooked even though I am in the older generation. Everything is done with such precision which makes the show flow smoothly along.  The story line is also great; it keeps you guessing about who killed Veronica's best friend Lilly ( shown in flashbacks), and why did Veronica's mother run away from home when Veronica was young (also shown in flashbacks and in the present), and who is Veronica's real father (also shown in flashbacks).  Add to all this that all of Veronica's past and present boy friends have rich parents and live in a swanky California town and you have a great program.  There are also some flashbacks about her boy friends which add to the mysterious atmosphere of the show.  It is well worth watching and I am only watching the first season with 2 more to go.
Great program. My wife is addicted.

We've been binge-watching this series over the last few nights. It's a bit stereo-typical of California High Schools, but there are enough clever (and touching) points to make it a fun watch. Fun for the entire family? Well there's no nudity if that's what you're worried about, but there are adult situations and the implication of teen sex--but no sex scenes--so PG-13 (at least not so far). The violence is often implied, but there none-the-less. It paints a picture of a class of kids too rich and privileged for their own good and those that have to live and go to school with them--every day.

My only issue is the casting. Yes, they're all (mostly) good actors but seriously? The star (Kirsten Bell) looks her age (she's 24) as does most of the cast. The scenes where she's young don't really work (just pigtails)--seriously? Yes, it's tough to get good, experienced performances out of teens who are still dealing with hormones and stage parents. ;)

I had never seen the Veronica Mars TV series until after I watched the Veronica Mars Movie.  i am viewing the series as a well developed Prequel to the Movie.  I loved the long running murder story lines and the development of the characters as the year went on.

I was unsure about how a few of the characters would fit in to a long running series, but after a few episodes, they began to be less of an exaggerated  stereotype, and began to fill in the back stories.
This is a great show.

What a sharp, well-written show, with generally excellent acting, ascerbic humor, and even an interesting twisty plot that keeps you thinking. Kristen Bell is engaging, witty, and identifiable as the lead character in this Ally McBeal-esque series. The relationship with her father is a plot line itself, and serves as a thoughtful example for single parent families -- while Veronica's character is highly insightful and intelligent, as well as independent to an extraordinary (sometimes dangerous) degree, it is clear that her adult characteristics result from the loving and insightful care of her father. My wife and I both love this show and thoroughly enjoy watching it.

An additional treat is to look at Kristen Bell's acting ability even ten years ago, which is absolutely admirable.
The cast is well chosen and the shows are interesting, but it seems to be geared towards a fairly young audience.
Absolutely loved it.  Where was I in 2004 when this first came out? I can't wait to watch season two.

Veronica Mars was one of the best shows on television. The dialogue is snappy and well written. The relationships seem real and the main characters are people you would like to know. Veronica is a hard boiled PI of the noir style by the time she is a Junior in High School.  The premise is slightly ridiculous and completely believable at the same time, mostly sold by the acting chops of the cast. The mixture of arc and story of the week keeps the show flowing.  I wish there was more tv like this.
Absolutely fantastic show from episode one definitely a must watch. Not some mindless show. Way too amazing to not watch!

The show, Veronica Mars, holds my interest. It is about a high school girl who works with her father at his detective agency, but more than that, she solves mysteries for her friends and classmates too. I have always liked a good mystery. If you like mystery stories, you will probably like this series too.
Amazing show. Not to be missed. It sucks you in from the very first episode. Surprise ending. I love Veronica Mars.
